qas.question: What operational changes caused a decline in the numbers of palagi traders in Tuvalu?
What type of traders did the Pacific trading companies cease to use?
How did the trading companies begin to trade with islanders?
By what year were there no more palagi traders on Tuvalu?
What is the term for a ship's cargo manager?

context: In the later 1890s and into first decade of the 20th century, <a0_0>structural changes<a0_0/> occurred in the operation of the Pacific trading companies; they moved from a practice of having traders <a1_0>resident<a1_0/> on each island to instead becoming a business operation where the <a4_0>supercargo<a4_0/> (the cargo manager of a trading ship) would <a2_0>deal directly<a2_0/> with the islanders when a ship visited an island. From 1900 the numbers of palagi traders in Tuvalu declined and the last of the palagi traders were Fred Whibley on Niutao, Alfred Restieaux on Nukufetau, and Martin Kleis on Nui. By <a3_0>1909<a3_0/> there were no more resident palagi traders representing the trading companies, although both Whibley and Restieaux remained in the islands until their deaths.
